title: High-Tech San Francisco Home Lists for $29.8 Million
text:
A contemporary, high-tech house listed last week for $29.8 million in Pacific Heights, San Francisco.



Gregory Malin, founder and CEO of the development company Troon Pacific, which bought the house in 2014, said the project was a culmination of “all the lessons we’ve learned in the past,” referring to his company’s dedication to sustainability, wellness and construction quality.



The house is tucked behind a gated driveway guarded by a biometric security system. It comprises four en-suite bedrooms and seven-and-a-half bathrooms, plus a penthouse level with one en-suite bedroom and roof deck access offering “views, views, views,” of the San Francisco Bay area, said Val Steele, listing agent with Compass.



The house also features a one-car garage with a Tesla Powerwall and a two-car carport accessible by elevator, and a wine cellar.



The house has a LEED Platinum rating, the highest level of green building certifications offered in the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design program, which is designed to inspire project teams to support public health and the environment, and reduce owner expenses over time.



Mr. Malin said in brainstorming for the project, Troon Pacific looked at the chemical content of construction materials including glue and paint, and chose materials to try to mitigate the use of oft-used harmful carcinogens.

The 5,465-square-foot home was purchased for $6.8 million through an entity controlled by Troon Pacific. According to building permits, updates included interior renovations, seismic upgrades and additions to the main house and garage, as well as foundation and repair work, a facade update and landscaping.



Mr. Malin said the company invested over 25% more into construction features, including wrapping the plumbing lines in clay to minimize vibrations, placing rubber and/or felt between every piece of wood, copper or iron in the plumbing and drain system to eliminate leaking, and adding an air purification system to circulate fresh air throughout the house eight to nine times per day to reduce chemicals.



Mr. Malin referred to the garden level of the house as the “wellness floor,” which features a seating area with a fire pit, an outdoor kitchen, a yoga room, a gym, a sauna, a spa and a wet bar, “which can be used as a form of wellness in itself,” he said.



“People today are busy,” Ms. Steele said. With the house being completely move-in ready, Ms. Steele said she is pleased, but not surprised, with the large amount of buyer interest.

“San Francisco has a more discerning buyer profile that might be different than Cabo or L.A.,” Mr. Malin said. The design, location and views are still what is really going to matter to any buyer, he added, but looking at what you can’t see is important to understanding “why it’s worth what it’s worth.”
